importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's first hyperspectral satellite launch, a major advancement in national space capabilities and technological self-reliance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month calibration period before full operational status means the satellite's full utility will be realized by early 2026, marking a critical technological timeline for Pakistan’s space program.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
The H1 satellite is the first of its kind for Pakistan and is expected to revolutionize agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster response.
SUPARCO, Pakistan’s national space agency, led the launch and described it as a 'major milestone' in the country’s space programme.
The satellite’s hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle chemical or material changes on Earth’s surface, offering capabilities beyond traditional satellites.
Pakistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs emphasized that the technology will strengthen national capacities in precision agriculture, climate resilience, and geohazard risk identification.
The satellite deployment is seen as a key element of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), supporting infrastructure development in regions like Gwadar Port.
The mission reflects Pakistan’s deepening strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.
Pakistan has launched three satellites this year: H1 (hyperspectral), EO-1, and KS-1, with the latter two already fully operational.
Full operational capability of H1 is expected after approximately two months of system calibration.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the primary nation involved in the launch and deployment of its first hyperspectral satellite, marking a significant step in its national space capabilities and technological development.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is responsible for the design, launch, and operational management of Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, H1, and is central to the country’s space programme advancements.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the core technological achievement of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch facility in northwestern China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite was launched from this Chinese facility, highlighting international collaboration in space technology and Pakistan’s reliance on Chinese launch infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China provided launch services through its Jiuquan Centre and is a key strategic partner in Pakistan’s space programme and CPEC development.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An infrastructure development initiative linking Xinjiang, China, to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is expected to support CPEC by enabling better geohazard monitoring and environmental planning in critical infrastructure zones.

namedEntities.name: EO-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pakistan satellite currently in orbit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: EO-1 is one of the three operational satellites launched by Pakistan this year, indicating a broader trend of space programme expansion.

namedEntities.name: KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pakistan satellite currently in orbit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: KS-1 is another of the three operational satellites launched by Pakistan this year, demonstrating progress in national space capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Dawn newspaper
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dawn reported on SUPARCO chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan’s statements, adding credibility and public context to the satellite’s strategic importance.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the official spokesperson for SUPARCO, and his statements about the satellite’s potential impact are central to the article’s narrative.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs – Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The foreign affairs department of Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ministry highlighted the geopolitical and strategic significance of the satellite launch, particularly in relation to China and CPEC.

namedEntities.name: The News International
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The paper reported on the operational status of Pakistan’s other two satellites (EO-1 and KS-1), providing context to the broader space programme.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, marking a major milestone in its space programme. Led by SUPARCO, the mission leverages advanced hyperspectral technology to detect subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, enhancing national capacities in agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster management, and urban planning. The satellite is expected to support key development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) by enabling precise geohazard risk assessment. While full operational status will be achieved after approximately two months of calibration, the launch signals Pakistan’s growing strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological self-reliance. This achievement is part of a broader trend of Pakistan launching three satellites this year, with EO-1 and KS-1 already operational.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
